newsitem.title: USA: Plantings report no Freedom to Farm yardstick - USDA.
newsitem.headline: Plantings report no Freedom to Farm yardstick - USDA.

text.p: The Prospective Plantings report, issued early Monday, is at best an indirect gauge of the new "Freedom to Farm" law, a USDA official said Monday.

The Purpose of the report was to measure likely crop acreage, not survey farmer sentiment about farm policy, said Ray Halley, chief of the crops branch of the National Agricultural Statistics Service.

"You could say that same information represents how they feel is their best option concerning Freedom to Farm," Halley told reporters. "In the past, they've been very good in dealing with farm programs, making them work for them."
But, Halley said, the plantings report and its survey of 55,000 farmers was not aimed at judging the effect of "Freedom to Farm."

Signed into law April 4, it swept aside a crop subsidy system in place since the New Deal. "Freedom to Farm" removed most federal control over farmers, allowing them to move from crop to crop in pursuit of profits, while for the first time putting a ceiling on support spending at about half of recent levels.
